participant.affiliation: Member, Management Board and Chief Financial Officer

plist.p: So good afternoon, everyone. Welcome to the E.ON's Strategic and Financial updates. It's good to having you here in Frankfurt. Disruptive political events and challenging markets require clear answers. So our CEO, Johannes Teyssen and our CFO, Marcus Schenck will outline today how we execute our strategy putting an even greater focus on the value levers that we can control.

The formal presentation will last a bit more than one hour; thereafter we take your questions. Given that some of you could not come to Frankfurt today due to the extraordinary market circumstances, we tried to organize a solution so that we can also take some questions from the Web site.
With that, I hand over to our CEO, Johannes Teyssen.
Good afternoon, everyone.

Obviously, circumstances are extraordinary and for that it's already amazing how many of you made it possible instead of watching the boards. Less than a year ago, Marcus and I had presented our revised new strategy to you based on the conviction that our company will continue to face a very challenging environment in its traditional market, but also quite strong belief, that the sector, overall, will continue to present opportunities in the decades ahead. That overall assessment has not changed. On the contrary, we see it rather even reinforced by recent events.

Despite some minor improvements in prices and spreads in the last month, the overall environment for conventional generation in Europe, however, remains very challenging as the economic difficulties in many of our countries are more pronounced than expected. From the political front, decisions to reverse the lifetime extension of nuclear energy, within weeks, in Germany only illustrates a broader trend towards increased government decision and intervention. This is an environment that we have to face and work with.

Nevertheless, we don't simply accept an even lower profitability in the short term and stagnation in the longer term. Quite the reverse. It is especially in those times where strategy and especially stringent execution makes difference. This is why we have announced today the most far-reaching performance target in the history of E.ON and I believe outstanding to unheard (2:52) the entire utility industry at least.

We are now determined to reduce our controllable costs to defined amount of €9.5 billion in 2015 at the latest. This corresponds to a reduction of €1.5 additional billion relative to the level of 2011 or nominal terms even more if inflation is taken into account. The resulting cost reduction could affect 9,000 to 11,000 jobs and will most likely affect those.

Cost and performance measures are the necessary self-helping mechanism in the market environment. They are, however, not an end in themselves. We are building a better and faster company to control our own destiny in future and to be able to position ourselves in the most attractive segments to generate future earnings growth.

Since the last Capital Market Day, we have made significant progress in transforming our European portfolio and to focus on our best assets. We have to dispose of assets worth more than €9 billion and have, therefore, regained our balance sheet flexibility by reducing financial net debt by around €14 billion in the last 12 months. And I like to reinforce that we almost have half of financial net debt in just a year.

Despite the significant headwinds, I remain absolutely convinced about the entire industry. Energy will stay the core element of economic development, which makes it one of the few sustainable long-term growth businesses. At the same time, hardly any other industry needs now to change more rapidly in order to adapt to the new political realities, the new technologies, the changing competition and different customer demands.

Traditional value pools will decline and possibly not return but, at the same time, new opportunities will arise. Europe is still heading for a very capital-intensive transformation of its entire energy system while showing limited underlying demand growth alongside ample supplier. Therefore, we redirected even greater share of our resources towards new value pools such as renewables and decentralized energy around customer demands.

Outside Europe, demand continues to grow strongly and the regulatory environment is more welcoming. Expanding our presence outside Europe to capture these new opportunities is a natural, is almost necessary to easy development for E.ON. All this fits well with the strategy that we presented to you last November. We, therefore, despite the tough times today, see no need to change direction but we do need to run our businesses even harder, much harder.

Marcus will go in detail to the financials of this year and later years later on. From our perspective, to make it very clear, 2011 earnings are absolutely unacceptable. Our loss in the second quarter has significantly reduced profits for the full year is not what E.ON stands for. However, given that in the first half, we suffer from around €1.9 billion of nuclear effects with an adjusted EBITDAR (6:30) that are beyond our control. There's a limit to we can do in the short term.

In the midterm, next to a challenging marketplace, we are furthermore faced with an ongoing reduction of our German nuclear fleet resulting in a foreseeable loss of earnings that we have originally anticipated in the last year.

Accordingly, we see an even greater need now to work out self-help mechanisms, but also had to reduce our dividend commitment once more. This has surely not been done lightly. The payout ratios in 2010 and, even more so for the fiscal year 2011, however, are clear signals that even in such tough times as nuclear faces in Germany, we pay utmost attention to our owners. 2011 will mark the earnings trough for E.ON. Thereafter, EBITDA shows steady increase, opening room for the dividend to follow later.

Let me now discuss the operating environment for E.ON as we see it. We observed numerous political interventions in all European markets. In Germany, however, we now at least have clear visibility from the government on the future of nuclear power. Around 8 gigawatts were shut down immediately. 12 gigawatts will follow according to a set time line until 2022.

While disruptive for nuclear operators, it does not yet fundamentally alter the supply/demand balance. Compared to 96 gigawatts of reliable capacity available in Germany, 8 gigawatts looks a lot. However, compared to the 250 gigawatts of reliable available capacity in Germany, France and the Benelux, that figure looks much less significant and actually is.

But what about the 38 gigawatts of old conventional capacity that might be shut down in Europe in the coming years, you might say? They will have an influence. But in Germany, France and the Benelux, for example, we see 18 gigawatts of new conventional capacity and 27 gigawatts of unpredictable renewable capacity coming to the markets over the next four years.

So there is a reduction of reliable capacity, but not as much as one would like to see. This will more than compensate for the 12 gigawatts of old capacity that we expect to exit those markets over the same period.

Accordingly, the price and spread reaction was limited so far, and currently, no new build signals are visible in the Central European or any other main market. In such a challenging environment, E.ON will behave in an economically rational way and will evaluate all investments on a case-by-case basis within the portfolio context.

In France, we have concluded now that roughly 1,100 megahertz of our 2,300 megahertz of old coal capacity will have to be shut down, starting from 2013, as they have become uneconomic due to the difficult regulatory and market environment.

By contrast, however, renewable continued to benefit from a lot of tailwind. While we have seen cuts and claw-backs to renewable subsidies, the underlying rationale is not a reduction in general political support, but a rapid fall of costs. Both reduced costs alongside overly favorable subsidies led to temporary investment excesses, and authorities were right to weed them out.

E.ON is wholeheartedly participating in the transformation of our power system towards renewable generation. We are already one of the largest renewable players worldwide and have become an (10:28) leader in offshore wind. We maintain our preference for developing and investing in cost-effective, industrial-scale renewables whether wind, solar or biomass.

The system transformation that Europe and, especially Germany, has embarked upon is capital intensive and generally unproven, but we see new value pools emerging. For example, around decentralized energy solutions.

In Germany, decentralized renewable generations such as solar, photovoltaic and small-scale wind has grown from less than 2% of total power generation in 2000 to almost 12% last year. In the U.K., we expect the share of decentralized power capacity to grow from 4% in 2010 to about 1/5 in 2035, with Micro-CHP taking the lion's share of growth for its account.

However, currently, each of the new products is marketed on their own merits, without a comprehensive view of the needs of the customers. It only makes limited sense, for example, to invest in superefficient heating if you're building a highly insulated house. Therefore, we see a growing demand for providing integrated solutions in the area of decentralized energy.

This includes services such as advising energy efficiency, offering smart home solutions, which would bring together home automations, smart metering, decentralized generation and storage services. Services around immobility, which would be a big power consumer for a household, also fits into the picture.

The challenge for us is to find the right business model in this area. We're not going to transform ourselves into big installer of solar panels, for example. But across all our regional units, we are working on ways to leverage our 26 million European customer base to generate additional new value from decentralized energy and transfer some of the learning to markets even outside Europe.

Moving to the global picture, it looks quite different. There, also, renewable generation is on the rise, but there is still a very significant demand for conventional power (12:50) generation capacity.

Power markets in the most emerging countries are still immature; therefore, significant growth of power demand is expected and large investments in power generation will be needed. Clearly, these investments will only come to those countries which allow investors to see an adequate return on their capital. While there's also downside potential to the growth dynamics expected for those countries in case the global economy falters, even a reduced GDP profile would still result in power demand significantly exceeding the growth in advanced economies.

With this environment in mind, we have asked ourselves whether the strategy announced back in November is still adequate. I can confirm that we have no doubt that we're on the right track. First, we do not see ourselves anymore as a fully integrated utility in any market. Instead, we only focus on those parts of the value chain where we can create the most value.

We believe that this are those parts of the value chain where we can make a difference through our own skills and efforts and harvest capabilities. These are all the businesses open to competition and scale and those stable business where we are not forced to invest, such as renewables.

To be clear, this does not mean that we will sell every infrastructure network or regulated activity. Instead, we will carefully balance the stabilizing contribution of individual assets to the overall portfolio on the one side with a cash flow consumption and overall value contribution on the other side.

Second, due to fundamentally different long-term outlooks, we will continue to expand on non-European operations. We will do this based on our successful entries into the Russian power market and our U.S. renewable business. And we will execute with utmost care under no time pressure. We will rather accept earnings dilution than value destruction.

Third, we have a fundamental belief that an outstanding performance culture is vital key to beat the competition and to secure a profitable future and also to count on the ongoing support of our owners.

Fourth, capital is a scarce and valuable resource and, therefore, we need to apply it in an even smarter and more diligent way than we have done in the past. So what have we done since the Capital Market Day? Is it just words or action? We have exited, noncore business worth more than €9 billion. We have, thereby, reduced debt, and from now on further disposal proceeds are available for profitable redeployment in our focus areas.

The expansion outside Europe is underway, priority regions are defined and our teams are working in the respective countries. Contributions from our U.S. renewable business and from Russia, including Yuzhno Russkoye, will help to expand the share of the non-EU EBITDA, to €1.7 billion to €2 billion in 2015. Value contribution comes first and, accordingly, we have consciously softened the previous targets to a vision of 25% contribution to total EBITDA by 2015, plus.

We're also working on specific transactions illustrating our less capital, more value approach. Put differently: moving from a pure design build owned model to a designed build partially monetized and reinvest model. Portfolios with existing wind assets have been created, and we are currently testing the environment to see whether there is an opportunity to bring in external investors at effective terms while continuing to operate and maintain the assets. Resulting proceeds would then be reinvested thus increasing capital velocity and allowing us to participate in those stages of the life cycle where we can add most value with our capabilities while allowing other inventors to benefit from stable returns once commissioned.

With respect to performance, we have to create targets to increase efficiency, transparency and control and to become top quartile in all businesses and processes. Since January, we have put in place a new functional setup and reporting of the group. During the course of the year, the improvement program, Perform-to-win, will come to a successful conclusion.

We targeted for Perform-to-win to improve adjusted EBITDA by €1.5 billion over three years, and we are fully on track to deliver this as planned. Nevertheless, Perform-to-win, as well as the additional €600 million communicated back in November, are not expected yet to lead to a sustainable cost base.

Since expected profitability has changed, a performance culture means that we now need to reduce costs even further. Based upon a series of benchmarking initiatives and stringent KPI-based steering. We have now set ourselves a goal to achieve the control of the cost base for these businesses we entertain not exceeding €9.5 billion by 2015 at the latest.

This comes on top of all previously announced measures, such as Perform-to-win and the additional €600 million, with a letter factually (18:38) only offsetting inflation. It is also a reflection of our new performance culture. Rather than implementing fixed programs with well-sounding titles, we were flexible to changing market circumstances and to changes in the expected profitability.

We will now investigate and implement swiftly a significant simplification of our legal and governance structures, especially in our German home market, an optimization of gas trading and support functions in Germany generation and a group-wide streamlining of administration functions. Overall, all those changes could affect 9,000 to 11,000 jobs. To make it clear, this is not business as we are disposing of. This is 9,000 to 11,000 less people in the same businesses. This is drastic, but we are convinced that we need to reengineer the way we operate.

Disruptive political interference, challenging market environments and expectations by the capital markets make this unprecedented target unavoidable and necessary. The benefits of the described preliminary results do, however, go beyond the pure lowering of cost by avoiding duplication by focusing on pure necessities in the businesses.

We hope also to become more agile allowing us to position ourselves at the forefront of this changing environment. We want to be transparent in the execution and will, therefore, update you every year where our control with cost base stands. If there are changes in scope, we will adjust for those but we're not losing our ambition level. Before I hand over to Marcus for the financial part, let me summarize where we stand today.

Ten months have passed since we presented the strategy. We have already made very good progress in delivering the corresponding objectives. We executed €9 billion of disposals. We regained balance sheet flexibility and restored our balance sheet. So other than other parties, we don't see any need to for rights (20:53) issue anything.

The expansion outside Europe is underway and today we have announced preliminary results for significant further efficiency improvements and these thoughts will be implemented, which should enable us to return to more healthy levels of profitability and position our portfolio for new growth opportunities.
So first now, Marcus, over to you.
Good afternoon also from my side.

Johannes has basically just outlined that our strategy remains valid. However, the changes that we have seen in the markets, as well as on the political front, are surely affecting our half-year numbers and also the medium-term targets. 2011 is going to be a truly awful year, and this is predominately due to a €2.5 billion burden on adjusted EBITDA related to the nuclear exit decision in Germany. They're up around €1.5 billion of one-off charges, €0.6 billion of nuclear tax and €0.4 billion of foregone margin.
In the medium-term, we need the additional described efficiency measures to return to an acceptable profitability path.

In evaluating our revised targets, please keep in mind that both 2011 and 2013 are on an achieved disposal basis. That means we exclude, in particular, central networks and the Italian gas distribution grids. While the new (22:32) number we are giving you for 2015 is on what you could call on a fully diluted basis, i.e., excluding the entire loss also from the outstanding disposals of around €6 billion; €6 billion obviously not being the EBITDA loss but the expected disposal proceeds that will allow us then to complete the €15 billion program. We expect the additional EBITDA loss to be at around €0.8 billion.

The implied debt factor in 2015 however, will then allow us to reinvest, as Johannes already said, the coming disposal proceeds into our described focus segments and regions which should also add earnings to that 2015 target that we're giving you.

Let me now summarize the 2011 first-half results. There's an additional presentation that we've made available to you which goes through all those numbers in greater detail as you are used to from our normal quarterly reporting.

Adjusted EBITDA is down €3.5 billion or 45% to €4.3 billion compared to the first half of 2010. A good part of this strong decline can be explained by the nuclear phase out; €0.2 billion due to the introduction of the nuclear tax, in addition €0.2 billion of foregone margin due to the moratorium and then plus an enormous €1.5 billion charge related to the disorderly shutdown, much higher than we had originally anticipated. That is a total burden of €1.9 million in the first half year due to these nuclear effects alone.

In addition, we have two negative developments that we discussed before; fall of around €1 billion in gas supply and sales and about €0.3 billion due the decline of achieved power prices. The strong decline of adjusted EBITDA feeds almost one for one into adjusted EBIT, which is down 61% and further down into adjusted net income, which is now down 71%. On the positive side, we have made further progress in reducing our economic net debt. Between June 2010 and June 2011, we have reduced our net financial debt from slightly more than €30 billion to €16.5 billion. In the second quarter, divestments, especially Central Networks, reduced net debt by another €5.2 billion. Provisions remained constant, at a level of around €17 billion.
I would now like to explain in more detail how Germany's decision to exit nuclear energy impacts our financials starting with the first-half effect and then I'll come to the full year.

The one-off effect included in adjusted EBITDA amounting to €1.5 billion are equivalent in the first half and in the full year 2011, and there are essentially four elements. €0.2 billion of write-down of nuclear fuel and spare parts at the two power plants operated by us, namely Isar 1 and Unterweser, €0.3 billion for additions to the nuclear provisions at those two power plants, €0.4 billion for additions to other provisions at Isar 1 and Unterweser. Those actually refer mainly to penalty payments with subcontractors started but not yet finished, investment projects and certain CapEx that was still underway.

And then there is €0.6 billion for additions to other provisions with regards to the two power plants operated by Vattenfall, Brunsbüttel and Krümmel. Both of those we consolidate at equity. In addition, we have €0.2 billion of one-off effect below EBITDA. The change in depreciation due to the write-down of fixed assets in use, which is about €100 million, is offset by the reversal of the interest charge related to the renewable energy fund which, you may recall, we had to book in Q4 of last year.

In addition, there are €0.2 billion of non-operating earnings driven by impairments; about half for our two owned plants, and then about the other half for the equity value that we have in our books for Brunsbüttel and Krümmel As I have just outlined, the one-off effects, I can now focus on the recurring elements in the years 2011 through to 2013.

We lose 3.2 gigawatt of nuclear capacity, although out of a total of 8.6 gigawatts, roughly 1.3 gigawatt for Unterweser, 0.9 Isar 1, 0.7 for our stake in Krümmel and 250 megawatts for our third stake in Brunsbüttel. However, Krümmel and Brunsbüttel were expected to operate during the course of 2011. Therefore the loss of output is proportionally lower than the loss of capacity. We lose 12 terawatt hours in 2011 and about 23 terawatt hours in the years 12 and 13.

You can see in the package we gave you for the first half year results that our hedge ratios for outright power has gone up strongly. This is not because we have hedged more. It's simply that by now we have excluded the nuclear output from Isar 1, Unterweser and Krümmel from the denominator; either 100% has declined.

For the loss volume, we lose revenues. We save, obviously, the variable cost. We also do not charge the fixed cost because that is now provisioned for and we avoid the fuel tax related to those power plants. In the short term, we had already sold forward almost all the outright power for 2011 and '12. As a result, we either have to produce from other plants or buy power on the market at a higher cost to fulfill our delivery obligations. Hence, the effect on adjusted EBITDA is slightly more negative than if we had not sold forward and only lost the production.

In total, this results in a net recurring effect; net in the sense that we include the fact that we don't have to pay the nuclear tax of €0.4 billion in 2011 and then, for the coming two years, it's €200 million to €300 million negative.
Let me now discuss the outlook for the full year 2011 adjusted EBITDA.

Compared to the outlook we communicated in May, we have two negative effects related to the nuclear phase-out. As of the first quarter, the 2011 outlook already included €0.2 billion of foregone margin due to the nuclear moratorium, which you will remember.

As discussed, the full year effect is expected to be €0.4 billion, i.e., €0.2 billion higher. This includes the avoided nuclear tax at Unterweser. And of course we have to take the 1.5 of the nuclear one-off effect into accounts. Note that these one-off costs are EBITDA effective but do not have an immediate cash impact.

The other changes to the outlook are relatively limited, first regarding gas midstream. We have started arbitration proceedings with Gazprom, the possibility foreseen in the long-term contracts, when a commercial agreement is not reached in due time. However, we expect to continue commercial discussion in parallel to the arbitration proceedings.

On the other hand, we have made further progress in our negotiations with other producers. So far, we have renegotiated more than 1/3 of the supply volumes and improvement relative to the 25% that we have previously communicated. Therefore, we now expect supply and sales to post a slightly lower loss than the €1 billion that we have communicated so far. However, this will be compensated by gas upstream and start of production for the Skarv field will be delayed by a couple of months.

All in all, we are lowering our outlook for 2011 adjusted EBITDA by about €1.6 billion from a range of €10.7 billion to €11.4 billion to now a range of €9.1 billion to €9.8 billion. We also lower our outlook for 2011 adjusted net income from previously €3 billion to €3.7 billion, to now €2.1 billion to €2.6 billion, and then translated into adjusted EPS from €1.6 billion to €1.9 billion, now down to €1.1 billion to €1.4 billion per share.

Let me now move over to the 2013 adjusted EBITDA targets. First, we need to adjust the more than €13 billion starting points for the more than €9 billion of disposals that we have realized since the Capital Market Day in November of last year. With about €900 million, this is the single biggest change to the 2013 adjusted EBITDA targets.

Next, we have the impacts of the nuclear exit. Net of nuclear tax and considering slightly increased wholesale prices, this is about the aforementioned minus €0.2 billion to minus €0.3 billion in 2013. Still on the negative side, we have a series of effects which generally reflect the worsening conditions of our sector and the slower-than-expected economic recovery.

While each single effect is not material, the total sum of those is almost €1 billion. Just a few examples, and you will see some of them or maybe more, a timing effect. We have delays due to the startup of the coal-fired new build (33:09) plants, partially due to permitting issues.

We also have delays to the Livorno LNG terminal. There's a clear deterioration of the overall outlook for our generation activities in both Italy and Spain, given the economies there are not recovering. There are several negative regulatory developments in Eastern Europe and, most recently, we've also seen one in Russia.

On the positive side, we observed slightly increased commodity prices relative to our assumptions that we communicated at the Capital Market Day in November last year. With respect to the additional performance measures outlined by Johannes, our preliminary targets are for about 50% of the targeted improvements of around €1.5 million to contribute already in 2013 to the EBITDA number. Overall, we are conscious of the fact that was a new headline target range of €11.6 billion to €12.3 billion, should be in line with your expectations, the earnings contributed underneath that are different.

Lower results in our operations due to poorer market circumstances will be offset by the increased performance measures. Note, also, that there have been no change to our expectations for global gas supply and sales. Here, we continue to assume a return to a normal level of earnings by the year 2013.

Let me now briefly talk about CapEx. Our previous CapEx plan still included some amounts related to Central Networks and to some other businesses that we have divested now. Over the period 2011 to 2013, this has reduced CapEx by €1.4 billion. Against this, we have increased CapEx in other segments where we see attractive opportunities especially in renewables, that's the lion's share, and then, to some extent, in upstream oil and gas. Please remember that there is roughly an additional €6 billion of growth CapEx to come as further disposal proceeds will be reinvested.

Let me now move to the mid-term outlook. Starting with the 2013 adjusted EBITDA, I will move down further in the P&L to the bottom line. Compared to the Capital Market Day, the changes to our assumptions for depreciation net interest income reflect the €9 billion of disposals already carried out and the increase of CapEx.

The assumed tax rate on adjusted pre-tax profit is between 26% and 30%. Please note that the effective tax rate in that year can be very different. This is a number which is very difficult to predict, but it should normally be in that range. Minorities are assumed to be at around €500 million. Adjusted net income would thus come out at between €3.2 billion and €3.7 billion, which would translate into adjusted EPS between €1.7 and €2 per share.

We also want to give you an even longer term perspective by giving out a glance of some 2015 figures. Compared to 2013, the main drivers would be as follows. On the negative side, as I said earlier, further dilution to the full €15 billion of disposals instead of €9 billion achieve so far. In the numbers on the chart, we do not include any reinvestment returns out of those additional disposals.

On the positive side, higher commodity prices is, unlike 2013, we have not sold forward volumes so far. More productive CapEx, for example, from those delays (37:10) and Livorno, are coming online. And of course, the full impact of our new performance measures, as presented by Johannes, should support earnings in 2015.

As a result, we are expecting an adjusted EBITDA between €12.5 billion and €13 billion in 2015. That translates into an adjusted EPS of €2 to €2.3 per share, once again including the total dilution effect, but not considering any additional reinvestments. The implied debt factor in that year will be below 2.5, which will give us the necessary strategic flexibility and room to invest around €6 billion, i.e. those additional proceeds that we expect from the additional disposals to be done.

Finally now on dividends and dividend policy. We generally continue to see a payout ratio of 50% to 60% of adjusted net income as providing an appropriate balance between, on the one hand, shareholder remuneration and capital discipline on the other side and financial means to provide further growth on the other side. It is clear, however, that adjusted net income will be abnormally low in 2011, in particular, given the one-off effect. Therefore, we have taken 2013 as a more appropriate reference point in our thinking about dividends.

Furthermore, we do not want to set dividends for 2011 or 2012 at levels which might not be sustainable afterwards. Given the deterioration E.ON's economic environment, the minimum dividend of €1.30 per share that we had previously announced for 2011 and 2012, does not satisfy these criteria. Even in 2013, the payout ratio would have been between 65% and 75%. As we always want to provide an attractive financial profile in the long run, we considered that range to be too high.

We have concluded that a dividend of minimum €1.1 is appropriate for 2013. This would correspond to a payout ratio 55% to 65%, which would still be on the high end of our target range but adequate due to the balance the aforementioned elements. For the two years before, we suggest or we would propose following €1.00 per share for 2011 and €1.10 for the fiscal year 2012.
That completes my part on the financial update and the outlook, and I will hand over now once again to Johannes.
Thanks, Marcus.

He has shown you the expected financial development. I would now like to explain where those numbers come from and, more generally, how you should think about the E.ON equity story in the years to come.

Our ambition is far reaching and stays far reaching. We want to transform E.ON from a portfolio of European national utilities into a global energy solutions provider. While every one of you might be convinced at first sight, for some the vision is too abstract; for some it sounds like a risky venture.

Please remember, that only a little more than 10 years ago, E.ON or its predecessor companies used to be predominantly a national utility or collection of conglomerates. In a relatively short time span, we have then developed into a European energy utility. We are now growing the next steps, focusing on only selected energy solutions and focusing on promising growth markets. This will result in full benefits.

First, a more balanced geographic business mix. Already by 2013, Germany will account for less than 50% of our EBITDA. In the years thereafter, the share will decline further as our existing businesses like Russia will grow faster, and a higher share of additional growth CapEx will be invested into our focus areas. This overall reduces the dependency on any single jurisdiction, while still offering synergies if operations are run from single platforms and not from multiple independent national solutions.

The second benefit, a reduction in carbon emissions giving proof to our cleaner and better energy heading. In Europe, the sale of renewables in our power generation fuel mix will more than double to above 20% by 2020. The carbon intensity, however, will slightly increase from today's levels as the share of nuclear production declines. We are, however, still financially long CO2. Every euro increase in the CO2 price results in a net benefits to E.ON.

Third benefit, a change in the risk and return composition to what businesses that we can influence, while paying attention to a balanced risk contribution. Traditional regulatory activities will be declining; however, stable, non-regulated activities are increasing. Here, I'm referring to non-merchant renewable businesses for earning streams dominated by capacity payments, like in Russia.

Overall, we want to increase the contribution of those businesses. But we can make a difference through our own efforts and our own capabilities without significantly altering the group's risk exposure. Finally, new earnings growth drivers, other than German nuclear or gas midstream, will increasing the shape of E.ON story, and I will quickly discuss a sample of those on the remaining slides.

Renewables are a key examples of such an earnings contributor. From less than 4.4 gigawatts in 2007, E.ON's renewables, capacity has grown our operational investments to 3.6 gigawatts at the end of last year. On the basis of our current investment plan, capacity will surpass the 5 gigawatt mark by 2013.

This figure could be further topped by reinvestments on the remaining €6 billion of disposable proceeds. In 2013, renewables are expected to contribute €1.2 to €1.6 billion of adjusted EBITDA. We have superior expertise in all key technologies. Next to long-standing hydro experience, we are especially proud of our onshore and offshore wind know-how.

In the U.S., which forms part of our (44:03) emissions, we are progressing towards achieving our goal of an availability of more than 98%. The load factor remains at high levels; almost 30% last year and even 37% in the first half of 2011.

Russia is another existing operation that forms part of our non-EU business. It has delivered a strong result in 2010, and we expect this development to continue. The capacity framework, together with the free energy market, is clearly a system which is supportive for our investments.

For older plants, the capacity fees cover the fixed cost, a significant improvement on the prior situation for efficient capacities. But for the plants built since 2007, the capacity fees do not only cover fixed costs, but also the full capital costs, including an adequate return on investment. In this attractive environment, we continue to increase our power generation capacity.

In November last year, we had commissioned the 400 megawatt Surgutskaya CCGT. In July, Prime Minister Putin officially commissioned (45:12) to get a 800 CCGT at Surgutskaya in Western Siberia. Furthermore, we are about to commission the last CCGT of our current Russian new built program, the 400 megawatt Yajviskaya. That leaves an only the 800 megawatt the Surgutskaya coal-fired plant to be built, a project that we have started and plan to complete by the end of 2014.

All these new units will benefit from the favorable capacity fees granted to new builds which, as I said, not only cover fixed costs but provide a remuneration of the invested capital based on an assumed ROC of 13% over 15 years. We have also kept both fuel and non-fuel costs strongly in check. Together with continuous optimization efforts, this has further improved our already strong position in the merit order.

Finally, wholesale power prices on the energy market are expected to increase due to economic growth.
